setup.pg-code: $step1 = RadioButtons( ["Solve the equation.", "Analyze data, identify trends, and predict the effects of change.", "Describe the relationships between the variables involved.", "Make a table of values."], 2, );

statement.p: What is the first step in creating a mathematical model?

solution.p: Describe the relationships between the variables involved.

statement.p: What is the first step in creating a mathematical model?

li.p: Solve the equation.
Analyze data, identify trends, and predict the effects of change.
Describe the relationships between the variables involved.
Make a table of values.

solution.p: Describe the relationships between the variables involved.

statement.p: The gas tank in Rosa's Toyota Prius holds 11 gallons, and she gets 48 miles to the gallon.

li.p: Write an equation for the amount of gasoline, g, left in the tank after Rosa has driven for d miles.
Find the intercepts of the graph.
The d-intercept is .
The g-intercept is .
What do they tell us about the problem situation?
The d-intercept gives:
The g-intercept: gives

hint.p: Rewrite the sentence with mathematical symbols: \small{(\text{gasoline left}) = (\text{gallons in full tank}) - (\text{mileage rate}) \times (\text{miles driven})}

li.p: (528,0): After Rosa drives 528 miles, the tank will be empty.
(0,11): The tank has 11 gallons before Rosa begins driving.

statement.p: The gas tank in Rosas Toyota Prius holds 11 gallons, and she gets 48 miles to the gallon.

li.p: Write an equation for the amount of gasoline, g\text{,} left in the tank after Rosa has driven for d miles.
Find the intercepts of the graph.
The d-intercept is .
The g-intercept is .
What do they tell us about the problem situation?
The d-intercept gives:
miles Rosa can drive before the tank is empty
miles to the next gas stop
gallons of gasoline before Rosa begins driving
gallons of gasoline per mile of driving
The g-intercept: gives
miles Rosa can drive before the tank is empty
miles to the next gas stop
gallons of gasoline before Rosa begins driving
gallons of gasoline per mile of driving

hint.p: Rewrite the sentence with mathematical symbols:

li.p: (528,0)\text{:} After Rosa drives 528 miles, the tank will be empty.
(0,11)\text{:} The tank has 11 gallons before Rosa begins driving.

setup.pg-code: $which1 = RadioButtons( ["\(y=mx+b\)", "\(Ax+By=C\)", "Any equation whose graph is a straight line.", "Set \(x=0\) and solve for \(y\)."], 1, );

statement.p: What is the general form of a linear equation?
What is the general form of a linear equation?

li.p: Any equation whose graph is a straight line.
Set x=0 and solve for y.

setup.pg-code: $threeways = RadioButtons( ["By inputs, outputs, or evaluation", "By tables, equations, or graphs", "By the intercepts, the slope, or the vertex", "By numbers, letters, or diagrams"], 1, );

statement.p: Name three ways to represent a relationship between variables.

solution.p: By tables, equations, or graphs

statement.p: Name three ways to represent a relationship between variables.

li.p: By inputs, outputs, or evaluation
By tables, equations, or graphs
By the intercepts, the slope, or the vertex
By numbers, letters, or diagrams

solution.p: By tables, equations, or graphs

statement.p: Write an equation for the cost C of renting a bicycle for t hours if the subscription fee is $7 and the rental fee is $2.50 per hour.
Write an equation for the cost C of renting a bicycle for t hours if the subscription fee is $7 and the rental fee is $2.50 per hour.

statement.p: What sort of variables can be described by a linear model?

solution.p: Variables that change at a constant rate

statement.p: What sort of variables can be described by a linear model?

li.p: Increasing variables
Variables that change at a constant rate
Variables that describe time
Variables that can be graphed

solution.p: Variables that change at a constant rate

statement.p: In the preceding Example, how long can you bicycle for $9.50?
Answer: hr.
Show this on the graph.

hint.p: Start by finding $9.50 on the Cost (vertical axis). Then find the point on the graph with C-coordinate $9.50. Finally, find the t-coordinate of that point.

solution.p: 1.5 hours
A figure is below.

statement.p: Consider the expression C = 5 + 3t. Finding a value of C when we know t is called the expression. Finding a value of t when we know C is called the equation.

solution.p: evaluating; solving

?
solving
evaluating
the expression. Finding a value of t when we know C is called

setup.pg-code: $gas = RadioButtons( ["At least 7.5 gallons", "At most 7.5 gallons", "At least 20 gallons.", "At most 240 gallons"], 1, );

statement.p: Leon forgot to reset his odometer after his last fill-up, but he thinks he has driven at least 150 miles. How much gas does he have left?
Show this on the graph.

hint.p: Locate 150 miles on the d-axis. What part of the axis represents "at least" 150 miles? Find the points on the graph with d-coordinates at least 150. What are the g-coordinates of those points?

solution.p: At mos 7.5 gallon

statement.p:
Leon forgot to reset his odometer after his last fill-up, but he thinks he has driven at least 150 miles. How much gas does he have left?
At least 7.5 gallons
At most 7.5 gallons
At least 20 gallons.
At most 240 gallons
Show this on the graph.

hint.p: Locate 150 miles on the d-axis. What part of the axis represents at least 150 miles? Find the points on the graph with d-coordinates at least 150. What are the g-coordinates of those points?

solution.p: At mos 7.5 gallon

statement.p: Find the intercepts of the graph of y=-9-\dfrac{3}{2}x . Enter each intercept as an ordered pair.
The x-intercept is .
The y-intercept is .

solution.p: We find the x-intercept by setting y=0 and solving for x to learn that x=, so the x-intercept is .
We find the y-intercept by setting x=0 and solving for y to learn that y=, so the y-intercept is .

statement.p: Find the intercepts of the graph of y=-9-\dfrac{3}{2}x \text{.} Enter each intercept as an ordered pair.
The x-intercept is .
The y-intercept is .

solution.p: We find the x-intercept by setting y=0 and solving for x to learn that x=-6\text{,} so the x-intercept is {\left(-6,0\right)}\text{.}
We find the y-intercept by setting x=0 and solving for y to learn that y=-9\text{,} so the y-intercept is {\left(0,-9\right)}\text{.}
